bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Charles Augustus "Gus" Mager was born in New Jersey in 1878. Here is known mainly for the his Sunday newspaper comic strip "Hawkshaw the Detective," which was a spoof of Sherlock Holmes. "Hawkshaw" ran intermittingly from 1913 to 1922 and from 1931 to 1947. During the 1920s, Mager worked as an assistant on Rudolph Dirks' comic strip "Captain and the Kids." Other comic strips include "Jungle Society" (1904-1906), "Mager's Monks" (1904-1913), "Sherlocko and Watso" (1910-1913; an earlier parody of Sherlock Holmes), "Milliobucks" (1913), "Main Street" (1922-1923), and various other titles.
Mager was also an accomplished painter, whose work was widely exhibited. His paintings are in the collections of the Whitney Museum and the Newark Museum of Art.
Mager died in Pennsylvania in 1956 at the age of 77.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This small collection includes proofs of "Sherlocko," "Captain and the Kids," "Hawkshaw the Detective," and "Main Street." In addition to sketch and composition books by Mager, photographs, and copies of the magazine "Outdoor Life" in which Mager wrote and illustrated the column "Game Gimmicks."
Original art by Gus Mager has been separated and cataloged in the Original Art Database.
